title: Sarah Azhari
author: Sarah Azhari
content: Some people get used wallets like banks (mobile banking) just for tracking or knowing if get received money from someone or payment. But, I don't like them, because we're in a crypto world where don't need to install a bitcoin wallet like mobile banking on your phone if want just to know if received money or payment a week.Yes, I did it on explorer, I just put my bitcoin address into explorer and bookmark it on the browser (simple, on chrome android, setting it as a shortcut in hope page phone). If want more detail and receive notifications like mobile banking, you must register in your email on a specific explorer and subscribe. So if any transaction is on that address, you will receive a notification in your email.*Note:We should know, Handphone is one of the target hackers to watch your activity, your life is being watched because too many applications out there we can't research if that is safe (close source). especially if you are careless and always installed in what you like. As I can see on the service board, many applicants as user phones and prefer on his phones to install the bitcoin wallet, it's very dangerous for beginner (ex bounty hunter altcoin who never use bitcoin wallet but expert use metamask, trust wallet, coinomi, or another altcoin wallet), so be careful, start saving now, buy a laptop and create bitcoin wallet there, don't trust too much on your android because you being wathed by hacker.change immediately your habits before it's too late.

comments.author: cryptoaddictchie
comments.body: As much as I wanted to use crypto at all, but we should remember that we still need fiat money to use in our daily lives. Its not as if simple things can be bought by crypo. Yes adoption is kicking in but not all accept it yet. There is a choice not to install mobile wallet and use only the card of your bank and only withdraw when you need the money. About monitoring its the same.

comments.author: Grim_Fandango
comments.body: Quote from: Sarah Azhari on March 30, 2023, 07:16:11 AMAs I can see on the service board, many applicants as user phones and prefer on his phones to install the bitcoin wallet, it's very dangerous for beginner (ex bounty hunter altcoin who never use bitcoin wallet but expert use metamask, trust wallet, coinomi, or another altcoin wallet),It is not a wrong thing to have bitcoin wallet on your mobile phone as long you dont store large amounts of bitcoins on it and just use it as a hot wallet. Quote from: Sarah Azhari on March 30, 2023, 07:16:11 AMso be careful, start saving now, buy a laptop and create bitcoin wallet there, don't trust too much on your android because you being wathed by hacker.Having your wallet installed on laptop is not much safer than having it on phone as in both ways you can get hacked as long as laptop is connected to internet. It would be safer if instead using Windows you have linux or macOS as those are less prone to malware attacks.Best way to protect your crypto are hardware wallets so those who have money for laptop should have money for hardware wallets too.

comments.author: John Abraham
comments.body: As long as it's online, It's risky. No matter what device you are using. Hackers can get access to your laptop. Suppose you want to be careful with your wallet. You can be with your android device as well. But, in recent days, Hackers improved their malware. They steal data through the framework. You can read more here Android malware targets 13 bitcoin wallets and 400 banks Shared by lovesmayfamilis. taufik123 Shared about it here https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5444480.msg61893757#msg61893757. Let's back where I was. You can use two things. If you really want to hold for a long time. Use Hardware wallet and never store your information online. If you do transaction everyday or couple of times a week. Keep small amount (What you need) of Bitcoin on your Non Custodial Android wallet.

comments.author: Z390
comments.body: That's your choice OP, I do believe that having a crypto wallet on your smartphone is safer than having it on a browser, I found that ridiculous, I can uninstall my wallet from my smartphone since I have the recovery seed, but right now or should I say that since the past few months now I have been buying altcoins and bitcoin, imagine having to reinstall the wallet and import my recovery seed over and over whenever I found a new altcoin to add, it's stressful, and moreover this is why it's called hot wallet.

comments.author: FirmWars
comments.body: OP how did you put Bitcoin on an explorer? Are you talking about the browser? How many times have newbies been warned to never store Bitcoin on anything else than the Electrum wallet or hardware wallet? And you aren't even a newbie, this is a bad practice that could lead to loss of funds.

comments.author: Zaguru12
comments.body: Quote from: FirmWars on March 30, 2023, 10:54:09 AMOP how did you put Bitcoin on an explorer? Are you talking about the browser? How many times have newbies been warned to never store Bitcoin on anything else than the Electrum wallet or hardware wallet? And you aren't even a newbie, this is a bad practice that could lead to loss of funds. If I maybe right OP isn’t talking about storing bitcoin on Explorer. Bitcoin Explorers are used for many purposes, OP is using his to check for transactions status either maybe the transaction is pending or there is have been confirmations rather than opening is wallet and checking if the transaction has reflected on it. This is done by copying the transaction ID into the explorer or checking using the public address. Public address doesn’t online doesn’t mean your wallet can be compromised, it is only possible when the hacker has access to your private keys. Although a wallet address can be used by third party to monitor the transactions process of that wallet, that is how much comes in and what goes out

comments.author: Saisher
comments.body: The one thing that will put your portfolio at high risk is carelessness and misinformation, even if it is stored in a laptop or you have a hardware wallet if you don't know the basics and the latest about securing your coins no wallet you can use and can secure it.Security starts on yourself, not on your device, you are your own bank, and a bank has all the security in place to secure their money in vaults from bank robbers, so your mindset should focus on security and not the kind of wallet that you're using.

comments.author: Zilon
comments.body: I understand the fear OP. We live in a very sensitive society, recently it has been discovered that new android OS versions which includes android operating systems running versions 11, 12, 12L, and 13 are vulnerable, reason they are advised to update when ever there is a new release.And with the numerous applications and malware circulating both on place store and the web one might just give in to hackers too cheaply. It is more safer offline or preferably on paper. Android users are just at the mercy of their operating systems.

This is because with your laptop, you also install applications and also do some other things online. The advice sounded like it is the ultimate, while it is not.If you care much about the security of your funds and you got alot of bitcoin to save, then use cold storage metho where you don't even need to visit online at all with the device with which you saved bitcoin.

comments.author: TravelMug
comments.body: Yeah, although there are a lot of advantage of using banking apps, it's one of the most targeted apps by cyber criminals and even if you have a good security practice, they can still hack someone because they are just one step ahead of this game.And with crypto, it's more evident, our phone is always connected, and worst if we forget about it and used public Wifi, we might exposed ourselves to this criminals who might be just roaming around and looking for their next victim. So just be careful with our online wallets being installed in our phone.

comments.author: sunsilk
comments.body: I appreciate your concern but those mobile wallet app users are just like desktop users, if they know what wallet app they've downloaded, kept the keys on safe then there's not that much difference but only the device they use upon accessing the wallets that they have.Even the desktop wallet users are also targeted by hackers, these hackers, phishing methods and other types of reverse engineering, they're all targeting us and they don't mind whether we're desktop or mobile users.Quote from: Sarah Azhari on March 30, 2023, 07:16:11 AMso be careful, start saving now, buy a laptop and create bitcoin wallet there, don't trust too much on your android because you being wathed by hacker.Much better to save and buy a hardware wallet. But either goes effective as long as the user knows how to use them properly whether it's a mobile wallet that has keys, the same with desktop wallets and also for hardware wallets.

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: Quote from: Zilon on March 30, 2023, 12:45:27 PMI understand the fear OP. We live in a very sensitive society, recently it has been discovered that new android OS versions which includes android operating systems running versions 11, 12, 12L, and 13 are vulnerable, reason they are advised to update when ever there is a new release.All versions are vulnerable and this will not change, which is why it is important to regularly upgrade them with security patches. The only problem is that most smartphones stop receiving such patches after 2-3 years because they are no longer the priority of the manufacturer. Quote from: Zilon on March 30, 2023, 12:45:27 PMAnd with the numerous applications and malware circulating both on place store and the web one might just give in to hackers too cheaply. It is more safer offline or preferably on paper. Android users are just at the mercy of their operating systems.I would not agree that it is only the operating system that should be blamed, because users are actually the ones who install various apps without even checking what they are actually about. I haven't had any problems with malicious apps on my smartphone, so I believe that anyone can achieve this if they only follow some basic rules. These rules are actually very simple and consist of not downloading apps that are relatively new and have a small number of downloads, and to also be careful what permissions you give to any app you install.

And you aren't even a newbie, this is a bad practice that could lead to loss of funds. I think you're a bit confused with what OP is saying, he meant to tell us not to install and use a wallet on our phone as a bank, it's too risky for our bitcoins. If you want to check your transaction status instead, just use explorer, don't log into your wallet too often by smartphone. But instead of buying a new computer to store bitcoins, I would buy a hardware wallet that would suffice and also be more secure.
